content:
Art. 4.8. 
Effects of indignity
A person excluded from the succession on the grounds of unworthiness is deemed never to have had any rights in the succession, without prejudice, however, to the rights of third parties who have acted in good faith.
An unworthy person is obliged to return all the fruits and revenues that he or she has enjoyed since the opening of the estate.
The share of the unworthy person benefits his descendants, if the substitution takes place. Otherwise, his share increases that of the other successors of his degree. If the unworthy person is alone in his degree, it devolves to the other successors called to this succession.
